front.title: Problem Statement for Special-Use Domain Names

abstract.t: The dominant protocol for name resolution on the Internet is the Domain Name System (DNS). However, other protocols exist that are fundamentally different from the DNS, but which have syntactically-similar namespaces.

When an end-user triggers resolution of a name on a system which supports multiple, different protocols for name resolution, it is desirable that the protocol to be used is unambiguous, and that requests intended for one protocol are not inadvertently addressed using another.

RFC 6761 introduced a framework by which, under certain circumstances, a particular domain name could be acknowledged as being special. This framework has been used to make a reservation (a part of the DNS namespace that should not be used) to accommodate non-DNS name resolution protocols and avoid the possibility of namespace collisions.

Various challenges have become apparent with the application of the guidance provided in RFC 6761 to real world protocols and namespaces. This document aims to document those challenges in the form of a problem statement, to facilitate discussion of future improvements to RFC 6761.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The dominant protocol for name resolution on the Internet is the Domain Name System (DNS), as originally specified in and . However, other protocols exist that are fundamentally different from the DNS, but which have syntactically-similar namespaces.

When an end-user triggers resolution of a name on a system which supports multiple, different protocols for name resolution, it is desirable that the protocol to be used is unambiguous, and that requests intended for one protocol are not inadvertently addressed using another.

This framework has been used to make a reservation (a part of the DNS namespace that should not be used) to accommodate non-DNS name resolution protocols and avoid the possibility of namespace collisions.

describes seven questions which should be considered when deciding whether a domain name is special. Domain names that are acknowledged to be special are inserted into the "Special-Use Domain Names" registry. The initial contents of that registry included 25 entries, four of which were top-level domains ("TEST", "LOCALHOST", "INVALID" and "EXAMPLE"). Since the publication of , the top-level domain names "LOCAL" and "ONION" were added.

While some of the entries in the Special-Use Domain Names registry document use of a DNS-like namespace by non-DNS name resolution protocols (LOCALHOST, LOCAL, ONION), other entries are included for different reasons (e.g. EXAMPLE.ORG, EXAMPLE.COM and EXAMPLE.NET are reserved for use in documentation).
This document specifically explores the problems in the use of to justify the reservation of top-level domains in the DNS. Use of with reference to other domain names is not discussed.

section.title: Terminology
section.t: Clear and unambiguous use of terminology is important for the clear formulation of any problem statement. The DNS protocol suffers from imprecise and overloaded terminology (e.g. see ) without confusing matters further with terms and concepts from other naming systems that are similar, but different.

The following terms used in this document are to be interpreted as follows:
Aardvark (n): a medium-sized, burrowing, nocturnal mammal native to Africa; the only living species of the order Tubulidentata.
